awd_titl_txt: 2022 Frontiers of Engineering Symposia (US FOE, China-America FOE, and EU-US FOE)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Frontiers of Engineering (FOE) Symposia, organized by the National Academy of Engineering, provide emerging engineering leaders from academia, industry, and government laboratories the opportunity to share research insights to facilitate an interdisciplinary transfer of knowledge and research methodologies. The nature of emerging technologies and how they fit together to create products and processes that drive economic growth makes it essential that engineers understand research developments, techniques and approaches beyond their own discipline. The FOE symposia serve as a catalyst to spur engineering innovation and foster collaborative networks of researchers within the United States and between engineers from the United States and partnering countries. The FOE symposia are also expected to increase the visibility of engineering and to highlight the key roles through which engineers serve society.

This award will provide partial support for three Frontiers of Engineering (FOE) symposia, to be held in 2022. These symposia, organized by the National Academy of Engineering (NAE) in concert with international partner organizations, are for early career researchers. The meetings to be funded by this award in 2022 are: China-America FOE (CAFOE; July, 2022; Chengdu, China); US FOE (September, 2022; Seattle, Washington); and EU-US FOE (October, 2022; Bled, Slovenia). The 2022 CAFOE will focus on: Additive and Subtractive Manufacturing; Food Safety in the Context of Big Data and Genomics; Water Sustainability; Wearable Electronics and Human Health. Topics for the 2022 US FOE symposium are: Advances in Infectious Disease Diagnostics and Treatment; The Hydrogen Economy; Technology and Racial Justice and Equity; Conversational AI. The EU-US meeting will cover: Post-Lithium Batteries; Prosthetics and AI; Supply Chain/Logistics; Sustainable Buildings. Approximately 100 outstanding young engineers for the U.S. symposium and 30 from each country for the bilateral symposia will participate. Each 2.5 day symposium will include plenary sessions, break-out and poster sessions, and opportunities for developing collaborative research partnerships. Sessions will consist of presentations on cutting-edge research, innovations, and emerging research opportunities in engineering fields relevant to the symposium. As the scheduled dates for each symposium approaches, pandemic status assessments will be conducted to determine whether to hold each meeting in-person or convert to virtual or hybrid formats. FOE symposium papers, abstracts, presentation videos, and slides will be made available on the FOE website (www.naefrontiers.org).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Office of Emerging Frontiers in Research and Innovation (EFRI)

por.por_cntn:
The Frontiers of Engineering (FOE) Symposia, organized by the National Academy of Engineering, provide highly accomplished early-career engineers from academia, industry, and government laboratories the opportunity to share their research and technical work, which facilitates interdisciplinary exchange across diverse engineering fields. The nature of emerging technologies and how they fit together to create products and processes that drive economic grown in an increasingly competitive environment have heightened the need for engineers to understand each other's disciplines. The  symposia are a catalyst for innovation that fosters collaborative networks of researchers within the United States and across national boundaries. This award provided partial support for the 2022 China-America FOE held July 18-20 in Irvine, CA and Beijing; US FOE held September 21-23 in Seattle; and the EU-US FOE held October 20-22 in Bled, Slovenia. Presentations and discussion focused on topics such as wearable electronics, water sustainability, technology and racial justice and equity, conversational AI, post-Li-ion batteries, and zero-carbon buildings. The meetings included informal networking time, poster sessions, and breakout groups. Presentation abstracts, slides, and posters are available on the meeting websites at www.naefrontiers.org.

The following results and comments were obtained from surveys of meeting attendees:

China-America FOE (point-to-point hybrid)

Meeting format: good or excellent ? 94%
Quality of presentations: good or excellent ? 100%
Gained something useful to work/research from presentations//informal discussion in other disciplines: Yes or possibly ? 100%//100%
Identified potential collaborative opportunities//applications of interdisciplinary approaches: 100%//100%

I already scheduled follow-up meetings with a professor from NCSU to discuss possible collaboration.

I sent 6 follow-up emails after the meeting!

The symposium is interdisciplinary, which helps broaden my mind ? quite different from the professional conferences confined to my research area.

I really like the international component. I would not have made these connections otherwise. Also, the fact that the topics were related to but outside of my expertise was very nice.

I enjoyed being able to disseminate my field to the other participants. It was a great honor to represent it, and it made me feel good about the public-facing aspect of my role as a professor. Networking with people you may never have met in other contexts was great.

I appreciate the small size, single session progression, and varied topics. This is what makes FOE unique and special.

US FOE (in person)

Meeting format: good or excellent ? 98%
Quality of presentations: good or excellent ? 97%
Gained something useful to work/research from presentations//discussion in other disciplines: yes or possibly ? 95%//96%
Identified potential collaborative opportunities//applications of interdisciplinary approaches: yes or possibly ? 99%//93%

Comments:

I learned about reinforcement learning, which I apply in my own work/research on infectious diseases, from someone who applies this method in an entirely different context (automating automobile manufacturing processes)!

I am currently pursuing collaborations with two of these participants that each involves the submission of an interdisciplinary proposal. 

I spoke with N. Hull about a potential collaboration on using UV light treatment to potentially combat infectious disease threats. 

I identified a potential new approach to collaborate with a PI at the FDA for my medical device start-up.

Two new collaborations resulted from this meeting. In fact, I already started exchange of samples with another participant. 

The 2022 US FOE was excellent. One thing that really stood out was the diversity in the room. 

EU-US FOE (in person)

Meeting format: good or excellent ? 100%
Quality of presentations: good or excellent ? 100%
Gained something useful to work/research from presentations//discussion in other disciplines: yes or possibly ? 96%//100%
Identified potential collaborative opportunities//applications of interdisciplinary approaches: yes or possibly ? 100%//93%

Comments:

By far one of the best meetings I have ever attended. Any NAE FOE is two steps above any other conference or workshop I have attended.

The challenges we face regarding climate change, a rising world populations, urbanization, use of resources, etc. requires a multidisciplinary approach to meet. Getting insight to other disciplines and being able to communicate with other experts is key. This symposium was very useful for that.

On the technical program side, I really enjoyed learning more about how batteries work. On the nontechnical side, the most valuable part was the opportunity for informal interactions with other participants. 

The composition of the symposium attendees was perfect: a small number all around 30-40 years old and from academia and industry, the EU and US. It fostered much easier and fruitful conversations.

GRAINGER GRANTS

Two grants of $30,000 from The Grainger Foundation were awarded to 2022 US FOE attendees who developed collaborative research projects. The recipients were: 

Hee-Jeung Oh (Pennsylvania State University) and Manan Arya (Stanford University) for, ?3D printed origami biosponge polymers for capturing toxic chemotherapy drugs before they spread through the body.?

 Varun Kashyap (Medtronic) and Karthik Narasimhan (Princeton University) for, ?Digital clot twin for enhanced clot retrieval during the treatment of Acute Ischemic Stroke (AIS).? 

 


Last Modified: 02/21/2023
Modified by: Janet R Hunziker
